{
  "article_text": [
    "cluster algebras were introduced by fomin and zelevinsky in @xcite in order to study total positivity and canonical bases in semisimple groups .",
    "let @xmath3 be positive integers .",
    "roughly speaking , a _ cluster algebra _ is a subalgebra generated by a distinguished collection of generators called _ cluster variables _ inside of an ambient field @xmath4 which is isomorphic to the field of rational functions in @xmath5 independent variables . to obtain these cluster variables ,",
    "one begins with an initial _ seed_. a _ seed _ is a pair @xmath6 such that @xmath7 is an @xmath5-tuple of elements from @xmath4 with the first @xmath8 terms being cluster variables and the remaining @xmath9 terms being _ coefficient variables _ , and such that @xmath10 is an @xmath11 integer matrix whose top @xmath12 submatrix is skew - symmetrizable ; the @xmath5-tuple @xmath7 is called the _ extended cluster _ of the seed . _",
    "seed mutations _",
    "are certain operations which transform a seed into another seed . in mutating from one seed @xmath6 to another seed @xmath13",
    ", one cluster variable @xmath14 is exchanged for another cluster variable @xmath15 ; the elements @xmath16 satisfy a certain _ exchange relation _ which is of the form @xmath17 , where @xmath18 are monomials on disjoint subsets of variables from from @xmath19 .",
    "the role of the matrix @xmath10 is to dictate exactly what these monomials @xmath18 are .",
    "the set of cluster variables which generate a given cluster algebra is obtained by mutating the initial seed with all possible sequences of mutations and taking all cluster variables from the seeds that result .",
    "quantum cluster algebras were defined by berenstein and zelevinsky in @xcite .",
    "quantum cluster algebra _ is a certain noncommutative deformation of a cluster algebra with an additional generator @xmath20 lying in the center . under this deformation ,",
    "each extended cluster @xmath21 in the cluster algebra is replaced by the @xmath5-tuple @xmath22 , where the elements @xmath23 now _ quasi - commute _ , i.e. , for each @xmath24 , there exists @xmath25 such that @xmath26 .",
    "the exchange relations are also altered to allow for the fact that extended cluster elements must quasi - commute .    in @xcite , fomin and zelevinsky defined @xmath0-polynomials and @xmath1-vectors corresponding to an initial @xmath12 skew - symmetrizable integer matrix @xmath27 .",
    "they gave recurrence relations for the @xmath0-polynomials and @xmath1-vectors which essentially only depend on @xmath27 .",
    "one of the main results of @xcite was a formula expressing any cluster variable in terms of @xmath0-polynomials and @xmath1-vectors using only the initial cluster of @xmath28 .",
    "the main purpose of this paper is to demonstrate the existence of _ quantum @xmath0-polynomials _ , which is an analogue of @xmath0-polynomials in the quantum cluster algebra setting .",
    "quantum @xmath0-polynomials satisfy the property that any cluster variable in a quantum cluster algebra may be computed ( up to a multiple of a power of @xmath20 ) in a formula with the appropriate quantum @xmath0-polynomial and @xmath1-vector using only the initial extended cluster .",
    "it is conjectured ( and proven in some cases ) that this formula can be sharpened so that the multiple of @xmath20 does not appear ( see theorem [ thm : no - q - factor ] ) . by setting @xmath29 in a quantum @xmath0-polynomial",
    ", we obtain the appropriate @xmath0-polynomial for ( nonquantum ) cluster algebras .",
    "the organization of the paper is as follows . in section [ section : ca ]",
    ", we recall the definition of cluster algebras . in section [ section : f - polys ] , we recall the definition of @xmath0-polynomials and @xmath1-vectors as well as the aforementioned formula for cluster variables ( theorem [ thm : cluster - var - formula ] ) .",
    "section [ section : quantum ] is devoted to recalling the definition of quantum cluster algebras . in section",
    "[ section : quantum - f - polys ] , ( left ) quantum @xmath0-polynomials are defined .",
    "theorem [ thm : quantum - fpoly ] is devoted to proving their existence .",
    "properties of quantum @xmath0-polynomials are given in section [ section : quantum - f - polys - props ] .",
    "proposition [ prop : fpoly - right ] shows how to easily compute `` right '' quantum @xmath0-polynomials once the `` left '' ones are known . a recurrence relation for quantum @xmath0-polynomials",
    "is given in theorem [ thm : quantum - fpoly - rec ] .",
    "the last section is devoted to computing quantum @xmath0-polynomials in a particular class of examples where the cluster variables correspond to induced trees of the quiver which can be defined using the initial matrix @xmath27 .",
    "we show in the subsection that this formula may be used to compute all quantum @xmath0-polynomials corresponding to any @xmath12 exchange matrix @xmath27 of type @xmath2 .",
    "in addition , a formula for @xmath1-vectors in type @xmath2 is given .",
    "in the sequel to this paper , formulas for @xmath1-vectors and quantum @xmath0-polynomials will be provided for the remainder of the classical types .",
    "following ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 2 ) , we give the definition of a cluster algebra of geometric type as well as some properties of these cluster algebras .",
    "the proofs of any statements given in this section can be found in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 2 ) .",
    "[ def : semifield - tropical ] let @xmath30 be a finite set of labels , and let @xmath31 be an abelian group ( written multiplicatively ) freely generated by the elements @xmath32 .",
    "we define the addition  @xmath33 in @xmath31 by @xmath34 and call @xmath35 a _ tropical semifield_. if @xmath30 is empty , we obtain the trivial semifield consisting of a single element  @xmath36 .",
    "the group ring of @xmath31 is the ring of laurent polynomials in the variables  @xmath37 .",
    "fix two positive integers @xmath5 , @xmath8 with @xmath3 .",
    "let @xmath38 , and let @xmath4 be the field of rational functions in @xmath8 independent variables with coefficients in @xmath39 , the field of fractions of the integral group ring @xmath40 .",
    "( note that the definition of @xmath4 does not depend on the auxiliary addition @xmath33 in @xmath41 . )",
    "the group ring @xmath42 will be the ground ring for the cluster algebra @xmath28 to be defined , and @xmath4 will be the ambient field , with @xmath8 being the _ rank _ of @xmath28 .",
    "[ def : labeled - seed ] a _ labeled seed _ in @xmath4 is a pair @xmath6 where    * @xmath43 , where @xmath44 are algebraically independent over @xmath39 , and @xmath45 , and * @xmath10 is an @xmath11 integer matrix such that the submatrix @xmath46 consisting of the top @xmath8 rows and columns of @xmath10 is skew - symmetrizable ( i.e. , @xmath47 is skew - symmetric for some @xmath12 diagonal matrix @xmath48 with positive integer diagonal entries ) .",
    "we call @xmath7 the _ extended cluster _ of the labeled seed , @xmath49 the _ cluster _ , @xmath10 the _ exchange matrix _ , and the matrix @xmath46 the _ principal part _ of @xmath10 .",

    "one may check that the pair @xmath13 obtained is again a labeled seed .",
    "furthermore , the seed mutation @xmath61 is involutive , i.e. , applying @xmath61 to @xmath6 yields the original labeled seed @xmath6 .",
    "let @xmath67 be the @xmath8-regular tree whose edges are labeled with @xmath68 in such a way that for each vertex , the @xmath8 edges emanating from that vertex each receive different labels .",
    "write @xmath69 to indicate @xmath70 are joined by an edge with label @xmath59 .",
    "[ def : cluster - pattern ] a _ cluster pattern _ is an assignment of a labeled seed @xmath71 to every vertex @xmath72 such that if @xmath69 , then the labeled seeds assigned to @xmath73 , @xmath74 may be obtained from one another by seed mutation in direction @xmath59 .",
    "write @xmath75 , @xmath76 , and denote by @xmath77 the principal part of @xmath78 .    for a given cluster pattern , write @xmath79 , t \\in \\mathbb{t}_{n } \\}.\\ ] ] the elements of @xmath80 are the _ cluster variables_. the _ cluster algebra _",

    "let @xmath188 be a lattice of rank @xmath5 , with associated skew - symmetric bilinear form @xmath189 .",
    "we also introduce a formal variable @xmath20 which commutes with all other elements , and consider the ring @xmath190 $ ] of integer laurent polynomials in the variable @xmath191 .",
    "* definition 4.1 ) [ def : torus ] the _ based quantum torus _ associated with @xmath188 is the @xmath192$]-algebra @xmath193 with distinguished @xmath192$]-basis @xmath194 and multiplication given by @xmath195    it is easy to check that @xmath193 is associative .",
    "the basis elements satisfy the following commutation relations : @xmath196 in addition , we have @xmath197 the based quantum torus @xmath193 is an ore domain , which means that it is contained in @xmath4 , its skew - field of fractions . the quantum cluster algebra to be defined below will be a @xmath190$]-subalgebra of @xmath4 .",
    "our first goal is to define the quantum analogue of a labeled seed .",
    "first , we must make some definitions .",
    "* definition 4.3 ) a _ toric frame _ in @xmath4 is a mapping @xmath198 of the form @xmath199 where @xmath200 is an automorphism of @xmath4 , and @xmath201 is an isomorphism of lattices .",
    "by definition , the elements @xmath202 form a basis of @xmath203 , which is an isomorphic copy of @xmath193 in @xmath4 .",
    "the commutation relations of these elements are given by @xmath204 where the bilinear form @xmath205 on @xmath139 is obtained by transferring the form @xmath206 from @xmath188 via the lattice isomorphism @xmath207 .",

    "the next , we will assume all quantum cluster algebras @xmath28 under consideration have the following properties .",

    "this proves @xmath447 is a laurent polynomial in @xmath448 . since @xmath448",
    "are algebraically independent , this implies @xmath317 is a laurent polynomial in @xmath311 with coefficients in @xmath190 $ ] .",

    "it was conjectured that nonquantum @xmath0-polynomials always have constant term 1 in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* conjecture 5.4 ) .",
    "this conjecture was proven in @xcite for the case when @xmath27 is skew - symmetric , and also in @xcite in the situation where the cluster algebra admits a certain categorification .",
    "clearly , one can prove the existence and uniqueness of analogous `` right '' quantum @xmath0-polynomials by similar arguments as given in the proof of theorem [ thm : quantum - fpoly ] .",
    "however , the next proposition demonstrates that these polynomials can easily be computed once the `` left '' @xmath0-polynomials are known . following ( * ? ? ?",

    "the number of vertices in a tree minus the number of edges is 1 , so @xmath692 must equal the number of components in the subgraph of @xmath615 induced by @xmath655 .",
    "next , we state a formula for @xmath1-vectors in a particular case .",

    "[ lemma : gamma - k ] let @xmath56 $ ] .",

    "[ thm : gvec - trees2 ] the @xmath1-vector @xmath652 corresponding to @xmath616 is given by @xmath746 , where @xmath747 for all @xmath56 $ ] .",
    "the proposition follows immediately from theorem 5.1 and proposition 5.7 of @xcite .      in this subsection , assume that @xmath275 is an @xmath12 exchange matrix of type @xmath2 .",
    "recall that such a matrix @xmath27 may be obtained via a sequence of matrix mutations from the @xmath12 matrix @xmath605 , where @xmath748    we will show that each cluster variable in the cluster algebra @xmath112 corresponds to an induced chain @xmath749 , which means that theorem [ thm : quantum - fpoly - trees ] may be used to compute all quantum @xmath0-polynomials in the type @xmath2 case . also , we compute @xmath1-vectors for type @xmath2 using proposition [ thm : gvec - trees2 ] .",
    "denote by @xmath750 the collection of subsets @xmath749 of @xmath607 $ ] such that the subgraph of @xmath615 induced by @xmath749 is a chain .",
    "( a _ chain _ is an alternating sequence @xmath751 of distinct vertices and edges such that the edge @xmath752 has vertices @xmath753 for @xmath754 , and there are no other edges connecting the vertices @xmath755 . )",
    "[ typeaclustervars ] the cluster variables in @xmath28 which are not in the initial cluster are in bijective correspondence with the elements of @xmath750 . to be more specific , if a cluster variable corresponds to the set @xmath756 , then its denominator vector is @xmath757 .    for the acyclic case in finite type , it was proven in @xcite that the cluster variables not in the initial cluster are in bijective correspondence with the positive roots of the given type",
    ". in the acyclic case , proposition [ typeaclustervars ] is a consequence of this result .",
    "more recently , proposition [ typeaclustervars ] was independently stated and proven in @xcite .",
    "to prove the proposition , we will use the following combinatorial description of cluster algebras of type @xmath2 given in @xcite . in this realization ,",
    "the cluster variables are in bijective correspondence with the diagonals of the @xmath758-gon @xmath759 , and the clusters correspond to maximal sets of noncrossing diagonals , i.e. , to triangulations of @xmath759 .",
    "( note that two diagonals cross if they intersect in an interior point . )",
    "let @xmath760 be a list of pairwise distinct noncrossing diagonals of @xmath759 .",
    "write @xmath761 for the corresponding set of triangles . in this",
    "setting , cluster mutations are encoded as follows .",
    "let @xmath56 $ ] . to mutate @xmath193 in direction @xmath59 , let @xmath762 be the two triangles in @xmath761 which have @xmath763 as a side , and let @xmath764 be the vertices opposite the side @xmath763 in each of these triangles .",
    "then @xmath765 is the list of diagonals obtained from @xmath193 by replacing @xmath763 by the diagonal @xmath766 .",
    "one may associate to @xmath193 a quiver @xmath767 on the set of vertices @xmath607 $ ] .",
    "for the edges , let @xmath768 $ ] , @xmath769 . if there is no triangle in @xmath193 such that @xmath770 , @xmath771 are sides of the triangle , then there is no edge between @xmath103 and @xmath124",
    "otherwise , suppose that the endpoints of @xmath770 are @xmath764 , and the endpoints of @xmath771 are @xmath772 .",
    "then @xmath773 if @xmath774 are in clockwise order , and @xmath775 if @xmath774 are in counterclockwise order . the principal part of the exchange matrix @xmath776 corresponding to @xmath193 is given by @xmath777 if there is no edge between @xmath103 and @xmath124 , @xmath778 if @xmath773 , and @xmath779 if @xmath775 .",
    "note that @xmath780 .    in @xcite , buan and vatne",
    "characterize all type @xmath2 quivers ( i.e. , all quivers @xmath781 of the form @xmath782 where @xmath193 is a triangulation of @xmath759 ) .",
    "* proposition 2.4)[quiverlemma1 ] let @xmath781 be a quiver with vertex set @xmath607 $ ] .",
    "then @xmath781 is of type @xmath2 if and only ( 1)-(4 ) hold :    1 .",
    "any induced cycle in @xmath781 is an oriented 3-cycle .",
    "( in particular , there are no multiple edges . ) 2 .",
    "the degree of any vertex is at most 4 .",
    "if a vertex @xmath103 has degree 4 , then two of the edges containing @xmath103 are in a 3-cycle , and the other two edges containing @xmath103 are in another 3-cycle .",
    "if a vertex @xmath103 has degree 3 , then two of the edges containing @xmath103 are in a 3-cycle , and the other edge does not belong to any 3-cycle .    in particular , it follows that any induced tree in @xmath781 must be a chain .",
    "let @xmath783 be the triangulation of @xmath759 corresponding to the cluster at @xmath85 .",
    "proposition [ typeaclustervars ] is an immediate consequence of the following lemma :    [ lemma : diagonals ] the diagonals of @xmath759 which are not in @xmath784 are in bijective correspondence with the elements of @xmath750 . under this correspondence ,",
    "if @xmath785 is a diagonal not in @xmath784 , then the corresponding subset of @xmath607 $ ] consists precisely of those @xmath185 $ ] for which @xmath785 crosses @xmath786 .",
    "furthermore , if @xmath787 such that there is some edge between @xmath788 and @xmath789 for @xmath790 , then the cluster variable corresponding to @xmath749 can be obtained from the initial cluster by mutating in directions @xmath791 .",
    "the denominator vector of this cluster variable is @xmath792 .",
    "first , consider a diagonal @xmath785 of @xmath759 that is not in @xmath784 .",
    "let @xmath793 be the set of diagonals in @xmath784 which @xmath785 intersects .",
    "this set @xmath793 may be constructed as follows : start with one endpoint of @xmath785 .",
    "this endpoint is the vertex of a triangle @xmath794 in the initial triangulation such that @xmath785 passes through the interior of the triangle .",
    "the diagonal @xmath785 crosses another diagonal @xmath795 which is a side of the triangle @xmath794 .",
    "the diagonal @xmath795 is a side of another triangle @xmath796 in the initial triangulation .",
    "either @xmath785 intersects a vertex of @xmath796 , in which case @xmath797 , or @xmath785 crosses another side @xmath798 of @xmath796 . in the latter case",
    ", @xmath798 is the side of another triangle @xmath799 in the initial triangulation , and it follows that either @xmath800 , or that @xmath801 crosses another side @xmath802 of @xmath796 . continuing this process , we get @xmath803 , and triangles @xmath804 such that for each @xmath790 , the diagonal @xmath805 is a side of the triangles @xmath806 and @xmath807 . it is clear that the subgraph of @xmath615 induced by the vertices @xmath791 does not contain a cycle , since lemma [ quiverlemma1 ] implies that the vertices in any induced cycle in @xmath615 correspond to the diagonals in a triangle in @xmath784 , and @xmath785 can not cross all of the sides of a triangle . by lemma [ quiverlemma1 ] , the subgraph of @xmath615 induced by @xmath791 must be a chain .",
    "next , consider a sequence @xmath791 of vertices from @xmath607 $ ] such that the subgraph of @xmath615 induced by these vertices is a chain ( with an edge between any two consecutive vertices in the list ) .",
    "the goal is to find a diagonal @xmath785 of @xmath759 which crosses @xmath808 and no other diagonals in @xmath784 .",
    "if @xmath809 , then let @xmath810 , @xmath794 be the triangles in @xmath811 which have @xmath795 as a side . for @xmath812 , any two consecutive diagonals @xmath813 are the sides of a triangle @xmath806 in the initial triangulation ; also , there exist triangles @xmath810 , @xmath814 with @xmath815 , @xmath816 , such that @xmath795 is a side of @xmath810 , and @xmath817 is a side of @xmath814 .",
    "let @xmath818 be the vertex of @xmath810 which is opposite the side @xmath795 .",
    "for @xmath819 , let @xmath820 be the vertex of @xmath806 which is opposite the side @xmath805 .",
    "we claim that @xmath821 is the desired diagonal .",
    "observe that all of the triangles @xmath822 are distinct ; otherwise , there would be three diagonals from the list @xmath808 as sides of a triangle , which would mean that the vertices @xmath791 induce a cycle in @xmath615 . by construction , the total set of vertices from the triangles @xmath822 contains at most @xmath823 vertices .",
    "any triangulation of @xmath824 has at most @xmath825 triangles , so it follows that @xmath822 is a triangulation of @xmath826 .",
    "thus , @xmath827 is convex .",
    "this means that the only diagonals from @xmath784 that @xmath785 can intersect are in the list @xmath808 . to show that these are exactly the diagonals from @xmath784 which @xmath785 intersects ,",
    "consider the diagonals of @xmath784 which @xmath785 passes through as one moves from the endpoint @xmath818 to the other endpoint @xmath828 .",
    "if @xmath809 , then @xmath785 intersects only the diagonal @xmath795 .",
    "otherwise , @xmath785 intersects the interior of @xmath794 , and passes through the interior of another side of @xmath794 different from @xmath795 .",
    "this side must be @xmath798 , since the side of @xmath794 different from @xmath795 and @xmath798 is on the boundary of @xmath433 . continuing this argument",
    ", it is easy to show that @xmath785 intersects @xmath808 .",
    "suppose that the triangulation @xmath784 is mutated in directions @xmath791 , and call the resulting sequence of triangulations @xmath829 .",
    "one verifies by induction that when @xmath830 is mutated to @xmath831 , the diagonal @xmath805 is flipped to @xmath832 .",
    "the assertion about the denominator vector follows from proposition [ prop : cluster - vars - trees ] .",
    "the final assertion in lemma [ lemma : diagonals ] about the denominator vector is proven in greater generality for all triangulated surfaces in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 8.6 ) .",
    "let @xmath784 be the triangulation of @xmath833 given in figure [ fig : t0 ] .",
    "the quiver @xmath834 of type @xmath835 is given below .",
    "0;<1pt,0pt>:<0pt,-1pt > : : ( 0,45 ) * + 1 = `` 0 '' , ( 45,45 ) * + 2 = `` 1 '' , ( 68,0 ) * + 3 = `` 2 '' , ( 92,45 ) * + 4 = `` 3 '' , ( 115,0 ) * + 5 = `` 4 '' , `` 0 '' , `` 1 '' , `` 1 '' , `` 2 '' , `` 3 '' , `` 1 '' , `` 2 '' , `` 3 '' , `` 4 '' , `` 2 '' ,    then the diagonals @xmath836 and @xmath837 correspond to cluster variables in @xmath112 with denominator vectors @xmath838 and @xmath839 , respectively .",
    "[ typea - gvec]the @xmath1-vector of the cluster variable corresponding to the set @xmath840 is @xmath746 , where    * if @xmath841 , then @xmath842 ; * if @xmath843 , the subgraph of @xmath615 induced by @xmath844 is a chain , and @xmath845 in @xmath615 for some @xmath846 , then @xmath847 ; * otherwise , @xmath848 .    proposition [ typea - gvec ] was independently stated and proven in @xcite , and generalized to other classical types . for finite type , formulas for ( nonquantum ) @xmath0-polynomials and @xmath1-vectors were given in @xcite in the bipartite case and in @xcite for the acyclic case .",
    "the first part follows from proposition [ thm : gvec - trees ] . using proposition [ thm : gvec - trees2 ] and the notation preceding it ( with @xmath616 replaced by @xmath749 ) , it suffices to compute @xmath849 for @xmath56 - c$ ] .",
    "fix such an index @xmath59 .",
    "first , assume that there exists @xmath846 such that @xmath845 in @xmath615 , and the subgraph of @xmath615 induced by @xmath850 is a chain .",
    "then @xmath851 , so @xmath852 , which means that @xmath853 .    next",

    "the complete list of denominator vectors corresponding to cluster variables not in the initial cluster is given in table [ table : f - polys ] .",
    "the corresponding @xmath1-vectors and quantum @xmath0-polynomials are computed using proposition [ typea - gvec ] and theorem [ thm : quantum - fpoly - trees ] . to obtain the @xmath0-polynomial , plug @xmath29 and @xmath322 for @xmath870 $ ] into the corresponding quantum @xmath0-polynomial .    @xmath871 \\mbox{denominator } & \\gg\\mbox{-vector } & \\mbox{quantum } \\\\ \\mbox{vector } &     &   f\\mbox{-polynomial } \\\\ \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{1 } & -\\ee_{1 } + \\ee_{2 } &   qz_{1 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{2 } & \\ee_{3 } - \\ee_{2 } & qz_{2 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{3 } & \\ee_{1 } - \\ee_{3 } &   qz_{3 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline   & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{4 } & \\ee_{3 } - \\ee_{4 } &   qz_{4 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{1 } + \\ee_{2 } & -\\ee_{1 } &   qz^{\\ee_{1 } + \\ee_{2 } } + qz_{1 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{1 } + \\ee_{3 } & -\\ee_{3 } &   qz^{\\ee_{1 } + \\ee_{3 } } + qz_{3 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline   & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{2 } + \\ee_{3 } & -\\ee_{2 } &   qz^{\\ee_{2 } + \\ee_{3 } } + qz_{2 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ]   \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{3 } + \\ee_{4 } & \\ee_{1 } - \\ee_{4 } &   qz^{\\ee_{3 } + \\ee_{4 } } + qz_{4 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{1 } + \\ee_{3 } + \\ee_{4 } &   - \\ee_{4 } &   qz^{\\ee_{1 } + \\ee_{3 } + \\ee_{4 } } + qz^{\\ee_{3 } + \\ee_{4 } }   + qz_{4 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline & & \\\\[-4 mm ] \\ee_{2 } + \\ee_{3 } + \\ee_{4 } & -\\ee_{2 } + \\ee_{3 } - \\ee_{4 } & qz^{\\ee_{2 } + \\ee_{3 } + \\ee_{4 } } + q^{2}z^{\\ee_{2 } + \\ee_{4 } } + qz_{2 } + qz_{4 } + 1 \\\\[1 mm ] \\hline \\end{array}\\ ] ]",
    "the author would like to thank her advisor andrei zelevinsky for his many helpful comments and suggestions ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> @xmath0-polynomials and @xmath1-vectors were defined by fomin and zelevinsky to give a formula which expresses cluster variables in a cluster algebra in terms of the initial cluster data . </S>",
    "<S> a quantum cluster algebra is a certain noncommutative deformation of a cluster algebra . in this paper , we define and prove the existence of analogous quantum @xmath0-polynomials for quantum cluster algebras . </S>",
    "<S> we prove some properties of quantum @xmath0-polynomials . </S>",
    "<S> in particular , we give a recurrence relation which can be used to compute them . </S>",
    "<S> finally , we compute quantum @xmath0-polynomials and @xmath1-vectors for a certain class of cluster variables , which includes all cluster variables in type @xmath2 quantum cluster algebras . </S>"
  ]
}
